column16: The current specification is unclear regarding mandatory and optional parts of the specification. This does happen in some locations but not consistently throughout the spec.

column14: For the purposes of SDC, security conformance rules are as follows:
column16: Is this optional, mandatory, recommended?

column14: o    When transmitting PHI (Personally Identifiable Healthcare Information) or other confidential information over an unsecured channel, systems SHALL  use TLS or other equivalent secure transport protocols (determined to be sufficient through risk analysis) to provide a secure channel
column15: o    When transmitting PHI (Personally Identifiable Healthcare Information) or other confidential information over an unsecured channel, systems SHOULD  use TLS or other equivalent secure transport protocols (determined to be sufficient through risk analysis) to provide a secure channel
column16: In the case this occurs in a controlled network this might not be needed. Although I recognize the need, mandating this in all situations goes to far. Suggest replace it with SHOULD
column17: Make TLS a SHOULD, not SHALL
column25: If it's a controlled network, it is by definition a secured channel and thus this rule would not apply.

column14: · When evaluating security of alternative channels, transport protocols, user authentication, etc., a risk analysis SHOULD be performed and documented using NIST 800-30 guidelines of their equivalent
column16: Given the requirements above an alternative is not allowed….
column17: What alternative chanels?
column25: The first requirements are for an unsecured channel.  This recommendation is to perform a risk analysis even if you have a secured channel.

column16: Most of the spec assumes FHIRPath as an expression language. CQL is another option that is mentioned. The spec does not take this into account on all places. Please update accordingly.
column17: Expand on use of CQL
column25: Do this

column14:
-expression contains the expression if it is written in-line (as opposed to by reference)
- reference points to the expression if it's not inline. For SDC purposes, reference must refer to content from a library imported using the cqf-library extension. For CQL, if the expression contains the name of the CQL content, the reference URL can simply be the canonical URL of the library. If the expression is blank for CQL or if conveying FHIRPath or a query, the specific reference URL must look like this:
[canonical URL of library]#[id element of the 'content' repetition whose Attachment.data holds the expression] E.g. http://somewhere.org/fhir/Library/12345#a2
column16:
This is not inline with how clinical reasoning tyoically uses CQL expressions.
The reference may indicate the library. If absent, and there is one library indicated by the cqf-library extension – this library will be used.
In the case of multiple libraries, CQL indicates that an expression is prefixed with the ID of the library (CQL id, not FHIR library id). In the case of multiple libraries, the reference may indicate the default.
One could argue that, the presence of the library may make the cq-if-library extension obsolete.
column17: CQL library guidance inconsistent

column14:
...If the expression is blank for CQL or if conveying FHIRPath or a query, the specific reference URL must look like this:
[canonical URL of library]#[id element of the 'content' repetition whose Attachment.data holds the expression] E.g. http://somewhere.org/fhir/Library/12345#a2
column16:
If I read this correctly, SDC specifies that Library resources can have a library of FHIRPath expressions, each expression in a separate Attachement. 
This an intesting case but does require more description, including a profile of its own to indicate the library is structured as described.
column17: Explain FHIRPath libraries better

column14: This expression serves the same purpose as the initial.value on Questionnaire.item, except that rather than specifying a fixed value, the value is calculatable. The value is set on initial creation of the QuestionnaireResponse or upon the question first becoming enabled. If used for a readOnly and/or hidden element, the expression essentially calculates a 'fixed value' for the element. If used for an editable element, this extension sets the initial value for the element. However, the value may subsequently be overridden by the user authoring the response.

column14: NOTE: the set of candidate expressions is intended to be a starter set, not exhaustive. The user should be free to enter or look-up additional values. Systems should allow multiple selections in situations where the question is marked as 'repeating' and multiple answers are therefore valid, but should only allow one answer for non-repeating questions.
column16: Is this an intention or a spec element that is required? How is the distinction made? What look-up is allowed?
column17: Should candidateExpression allow prohibition of alternatives?

column14:
This is similar to candidateExpression, in that it is also only used when the user is editing the answer for the question associated with the candidateExpression. However, instead of giving candidate answers that can simply be "selected", this option instead presents potentially relevant information. For example, a question might be "Has the patient been admitted for this or a related condition in the past year?". To help guide the answers, the contextExpression could retrieve a list of admission reasons for that patient for encounters in the past year. The user completing the questionnaire could then use that information to guide whether they choose to answer 'yes' or 'no.

Also, like candidateExpressions, contextExpressions should rarely, if ever, declare a name element.
column16: This context seems to be different from the execution context. How should one read this – evaluates to background information on the question that is shown as read-only?
column17: Clarify contextExpression
column25: This isn't for read-only questions.  The user must answer a question - but they might want to look at the context information to help guide their answer.  Will add clarifying language to that effect

column25: This has nothing to do with whether the user can edit - that's driven by whether the element is hidden or read-only.  This is just about whether the value will automatically change to reflect the new context when opening an element.  As an example, if an element is set to be today's date and you store the questionnaire and then open it tomorrow, the date will remain the stored date because it is now different than the calculated value - and thus is treated as user-edited.

column14: This expression identifies the resource(s) that correspond either to an overall questionnaire, a group within the questionnaire or, occasionally, a single question. The results of executing the specified query are used to indicate the resources used to populate the item when performing population and identifies the data to replace when performing an extraction - and also indicates the relevant resource type.

column4: 10.1 Caveats and considerations with form population
column14: For form population to work with such data, the Questionnaire will have to be designed presuming the use of particular profiles and conventions - for example, national implementation guides such as US Core or Australian Base. The more sophisticated a Questionnaire's population rules, the more dependent it will be on systems exposing their data in accordance with specified profiles.

column4: 10.1 Caveats and considerations with form population
column14: While some degree of filtering is possible using FHIRPath, loading thousands or tens of thousands of records for local filtering  is likely to pose a challenge from the perspective of performance, memory usage, access control logging, etc.
column16: Why local? Is it the assumption that all processing is done locally? If so, what does local mean? The webbrowser?
column17: Why local?
column25:
Change 'local' to 'local filtering by the client'.

The purpose of the sentence is to indicate that you want any queried data to be filtered by the server (through good search parameter filtering) rather than filtered locally after retrieval.

column4: 10.1 Caveats and considerations with form population
column14: Users should not be able to see information populated into a form that they would not be able to see when navigating the source system directly. In some cases, this means that an answer in a form might not be populated even though the data exists - because the user doesn't have authority to see that data.

column4: 10.1 Caveats and considerations with form population
column14: … different metadata in the Questionnaire to support the population process. In this case, rather than invoking the population on the original Questionnaire, it can be done on a derived Questionnaire - one that has a Questionnaire.derivedFrom relationship to the canonical URL of the desired Questionnaire. The derived Questionnaire would contain the same content as the base Questionnaire, but would have additional extensions inserted to support population. Once the QuestionnaireResponse was generated/completed, it would be updated to assert a QuestionnaireResponse.questionnaire of the original Questionnaire's canonical URL rather than that of the derived Questionnaire that drove the population process.

column4: 11.3 Designing Questionnaires to support data extraction
column14: The sdc-questionnaire-extract profile includes the data elements and extensions relevant for supporting all these mechanisms. None of the additional resource elements or extensions are marked as "mustSupport" because there is no expectation that systems will support all (or any of) the different extraction mechanisms. Instead, each system should choose which approach(es) it wishes to use and support the elements described in that section of the implementation guide.

column16:
For the purpose of supporting complex logic, we propose to add the questionnaire-enablewhen extension (http://hl7.org/fhir/2018Sep/extension-questionnaire-enablewhen.html) to the list of extensions for this profile. Currently, when multiple enableWhen elements are created, the item will be enabled when the condition for any of the repetitions is true. I.e. treat "enableWhen"s as being joined by an "or" clause. Concatenating or nesting multiple conditions using different logical groupers like and, nor, nand, etc. is currently not possible. 
See tracker item #19023
column17: Add enableWhen extension
column25: We already have the enableWhenExpression extension for this purpose

column14: Conformant systems are allowed to ignore this extension unless the rendering-styleSensitive flag is set to true.
column16: Recommend relaxing this to a should rather than a shall.  What if the proposed rendering style clashes with the underlying system style, or could cause a safety issue if used as is?  It seems the rendering system should ultimately be allowed to have final say in the display (e.g., with a minor tweak), even if it should use the specified rendering if feasible.
column17: Allow over-ride of rendering style.
column21: Lloyd: The purpose of the flag is explicitly to ensure that, where the validity of a questionnaire instrument is dependent on style, that it is only displayed by systems capable of adhering to the requirements.  If the flag is set and the system can't render as specified, then the system can't legitimately display the questionnaire at all.  This is done to ensure validity of the answers.
